title: point size + leading and centimeters
content:
Hi,  
I was wondering how much a text block of 58 lines of a 10/11 pt type size/leading would make in centimeters?  
Does it change with each type or is it always the same?

thanks in advance for your time :)
author: jjshell

comments.content: It will change with the type. Point size is just a relative measurement. There will be some relationship in size from font to font but not a precise one. Sometimes the difference can be huge. If you want to answer the question you have to choose a type & then measure. Why do you want to know? What is your purpose?
I’m sure someone else would say this if I didn’t, but you need to do a little of your own research - check the definitions of ‘leading’ and ‘point’.

Actually that was a little uncharitable, plus I disagree with Eben!

If you mean 10pt type on 11pt leading, your lines will be 11pt apart, and so 58 lines will be the same height whatever font you use; however, the amount of text which will fit on this number of lines will vary.

You’re both right!

Height: ~22.5 cm.  
Width: Depends on the font.

And the font will also determine if such a  
fixed setting ends up looking right or wrong.

hhp

Oh, how I loved using my assortment of pica gauges, printer’s rule and my favorite 18″ newspaper agate-to-inch-to pica/point-to-centimeter stainless steel rule! Believe it or not, some guys even had scabbards for their “blades.”

_58 lines at 10, 11, 12, 14 points of lead converted to inches, agate lines, centimeters? Easy, just place your thumbnail at 58 and flip over the ruler!_

Or take your Haberule and lay it against a centimeter rule.

ChrisL
Elliot is right that it is theoretically possible to make different fonts take up the same amount of space by altering sizes & line space. Muy fancy.

The height of the block of text from ascender of the top line to descender of the bottom line will be 22.43cm (636pts)\* the top line won’t have any leading above it so it isn’t 22.50cm (638pts). This is only pedantry and won’t really affect a mark-up for text with such tight leading and the difference will only be tenths of a millimetre.

\*This figure is likely too high since the actual height of a font rarely takes up the full point size it is designated.  
Tim
thanks a lot for your replies :)
